intro: Corydalis racemosa, commonly known as the clustered corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of delicate, pink to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and meadows. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and have a hairy texture. Corydalis racemosa is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional herbal medicine.
